definition: See also the biological process terms 'viral infectious cycle ; GO:0019058' and 'lysogeny ; GO:0030069'.

A multi-organism process in which a virus is a participant. The other participant is the host. Includes infection of a host cell, replication of the viral genome, and assembly of progeny virus particles. In some cases the viral genetic material may integrate into the host genome and only subsequently, under particular circumstances, 'complete' its life cycle.

The process in which a relatively unspecialized cell acquires specialized features of a stem cell. A stem cell is a cell that retains the ability to divide and proliferate throughout life to provide progenitor cells that can differentiate into specialized cells.
The chemical reactions and pathways by which individual cells transform chemical substances.
All of the contents of a cell excluding the plasma membrane and nucleus, but including other subcellular structures.
Interacting selectively and non-covalently with the erythropoietin receptor.

The chemical reactions and pathways resulting in the formation of a receptor molecule, a macromolecule that undergoes combination with a hormone, neurotransmitter, drug or intracellular messenger to initiate a change in cell function.
Combining with erythropoietin and transmitting the signal from one side of the membrane to the other to initiate a change in cell activity.
